why is the Lagrangian T â€“ V, exactly? Why is it not the sum of the kinetic and potential energy?

First of all, the Lagrangian is NOT the total energy of an object, it is something entirely different.
The Lagrangian has very little to do with the total energy, it can rather be thought of as a state of motion at any particular point in time, which is described by the kinetic and potential energies (since they include information about both the velocity and position).
Now, there are basically two reasonable ways that you could describe the motion with these two quantities; you could try to describe the â€œstate of motionâ€ at each point by the total energy (T+V), or by the difference of the energies (T-V).
Potential energy, however, isnâ€™t really something that describes motion by itself. It can be converted into other forms of energy (namely kinetic energy), but potential energy itself does not describe motion, only the changes in potential energy do.
This is why it makes sense to describe motion by the difference of kinetic and potential energy, rather than the sum of the two; it allows for a sensible trade-off between the kinetic and potential energies (i.e. they can convert into one another) because of the sign difference between them:
Since the total energy (T+V) is a conserved quantity, it doesnâ€™t change with time. Thus, it isnâ€™t particularly useful in describing motion (although it can be made work in a different way, such as is done in Hamiltonian mechanics).
The difference in energies (T-V), on the other hand, is not a conserved quantity (meaning its values can change with time), so it makes for a much more useful tool for describing motion.
An interesting way to visualize this is by plotting the values for T+V and T-V for a pendulum (T+V being the total energy, which is called the Hamiltonian, but thatâ€™s not important for now):
This gives a beautiful way of visualizing how the Lagrangian actually encodes a lot of information about the motion of a system (in this case, for a pendulum), which makes it a lot more useful than the total energy for modeling the dynamics of physical systems.
Another reason for why the Lagrangian is the difference of kinetic and potential energy is simply because it gives the desirable results.
In more advanced theories of physics, Lagrangians are simply treated as functions that generate equations of motion. So, a Lagrangian is judged by the usefulness of what results it gives and there is nothing more to it.
In classical mechanics, this particular Lagrangian, L = T â€“ V, is precisely the Lagrangian that generates Newtonâ€™s second law, F = ma.
Ultimately, this comes from how forces are defined in terms of potential energies (the minus sign in L=T-V is what generates the minus sign here, which weâ€™ll see later in the article):
F=-\frac{dV}{dx}
To be fair, this Lagrangian of T-V is only really applicable to classical mechanics
To be fair, this Lagrangian of T-V is only really applicable to classical mechanics. For example, in special relativity the Lagrangian takes a different form.

Earlier, I covered what the action is (a quantity that describes a particular path through space and time). Now Iâ€™d like to explore what the principle of stationary action actually means.

Now, you may be thinking that this is interesting and all, but why exactly should physical systems obey this principle? Why should an object take the path of stationary action instead of some other path?
Fundamentally, nobody actually knows the real answer to this. Itâ€™s quite funny how the stationary action principle underlies pretty much all of modern physics, but nobody knows why it happens to be true.

The same kind of process could be thought of as applying to motion as well, but just as a much higher-level concept.
